author: sky.cactus
content: My *personal* philosophy is that once you have tried responsible disclosure via bug bounty program, and the bug bounty program doesn't say "we were already aware of the issue and are working on a solution" or "thank you for the report, we will investigate further and get back to you" then you have kept up your end of the responsible disclosure side and it is appropriate to post publicly (e.g., ethmagicians).

author: ajsutton
content:
I've said before but I'll reiterate here, I am not the right person to report security vulnerabilities in Ethereum to. For security vulnerabilities in Teku the process is described at https://github.com/ConsenSys/teku/blob/master/SECURITY.md (I get those reports but so do some actual security researchers who work with us who can much better work through all the details).  For Ethereum-wide things it tends to quickly get into crypto-economics which requires quite specialised skills to evaluate well and that's not my forte.
security@ethereum.org is a good place to report it. I'd give that a couple of weeks and if you don't hear back post publicly. I would be surprised if British lawyers were well equipped to reason about crypto-economic security and British law doesn't affect the security of Ethereum (it may have implications for people using Ethereum if they're under British law but that's not the same thing).
